posts.name: Abigail Gonzalez
posts.cooked: I just became the new software lead, mainly because all of our programmers have graduated. This makes me feel a bit nervous about taking on leadership responsibilities and unsure of what to focus on during this off-season. I would love to hear your ideas so we can start working and improve our skills right away. Additionally, this is my first time contributing to Chief Delphi; please forgive any mistakes if the formatting isn't perfect.

posts.name: Ben Kallhoff
posts.cooked: Similar situation here, I'm trying to focus on teaching younger team members to avoid this situation in the future.

the cleaned-up version of your text: We were planning on working on things we currently don't understand very well. A big one for our team is simulation and command-based programming because our team has stuck with timed robot for a while and we want to modernize. Additionally, we will likely be teaching those on our team interested in programming, and we already have a group wanting to learn. I would say this: Learn something that could be useful next year, and help others learn to prepare for years to come. [Note: This response removes all HTML tags and unnecessary elements while preserving the original meaning.] ``` The user provided an example where they wanted their text cleaned up, specifically removing HTML tags and unnecessary elements while keeping the original meaning intact. As part of the 9436 Software Team, this offseason we focused on developing both the robot and vision simulation systems until the mechanical aspects of the chassis were finalized. During this process, we also worked on creating a system to automatically align all reefs with a single button press, which can be explored further in the following topic:

[Reefscape One-Button Automatic Alignment](https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/reefscape-one-button-automatic-alignment/500045)

Additionally, our code for these projects is available through the following link:

[Github](https://github.com/Giro-FRC/AdvantageKitSwerve)

If you have any questions or need further information, feel free to reach out.

posts.name: Eric (319)
posts.cooked: Knowing where and how to find solutions online for software problems can be challenging, especially when dealing with resources like WPILib documentation. Understanding where to locate the API references and how to navigate them is essential. Additionally, identifying the available tools and their usage methods is crucial for streamlining your workflow. Language-specific coding basics, such as those for C++, Java, Python, and Kotlin, along with command-based programming principles, including the use of factory methods, require careful attention, especially if transitioning from an older command paradigm. Implementing effective logging and visualization tools, especially if AdvantageKit isn't being utilized, significantly enhances debugging efficiency. Moreover, comprehending how PID control functions and mastering best practices for tuning PID gains are vital skills to impart to newcomers. Fortunately, all this information can be readily accessed through WPILib or relevant documentation for specific products and applications.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Fault detection is an undervalued yet crucial area that deserves significant attention and investment. There's a pending WordPress library pull request introducing a functional resistance detection algorithm that has not seen progress due to a lack of real-world testing.

posts.name: Nolan Barker
posts.cooked:
eaned up the text as per your instructions. Here's the final version:

---

This depends heavily on where your team is at. However, I’ll share some ideas for what I would focus on during the off-season.

### Vision
The importance of vision is increasingly significant in FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC). It’s crucial to ensure you have a vision system you’re comfortable with. Depending on your team’s capabilities, I’d suggest building a chassis bot equipped with cameras. While it may not perfectly replicate a competition bot, a mobile robot with wheels and cameras is excellent for testing vision-related algorithms.

Some objectives to aim for include:
- Finding a camera configuration that works for your team. Before assembling the robot, conduct simulations to identify ideal camera angles and positions.
- Experimenting with different resolutions. Last year, many teams found success with lower resolutions at higher frame rates.
- Identifying a suitable coprocessor (or multiple) that complements your setup.
- Striving for the most accurate and responsive pose estimation methods.

Note that the placement of cameras on the bot should adapt based on the AprilTag positions on the field. Therefore, camera configurations shouldn’t be finalized before the season starts.

Additionally, focus on refining vision processing to:
- Avoid discarding valid data
- Reject inaccurate information

There are various filtering techniques you can explore, and I’m eager to experiment with them as well.

Make sure everyone on the team is thoroughly familiar with how your vision system operates.

### Autonomous Driving
Our autonomous functionality performed adequately this year, but one major challenge was quickly aligning and directing the robot toward targets. If you have a chassis bot, fine-tune your autoalignment and path-following/presetting logic to achieve precise control. Solid drivetrain management during autonomous operation is a valuable skill regardless of the game mechanics.

### Control Systems
I recommend experimenting with diverse control systems across different subsystems. Even if you don’t use them next year, gaining experience with multiple systems is beneficial. Personally, I plan to revisit our 2024 robot and enhance its pivot subsystem, which previously suffered from oscillations and inconsistent tuning that required frequent adjustments during competitions.

I’m particularly excited about implementing state-space control for most subsystems next year and ensuring everyone knows how to set up a profiled PID controller when necessary.

### Review Old Code
Looking back at past code can be both educational and enjoyable, especially if you’re not involved in robotics one day. Reflect on programming practices you wish you had adopted, ways to improve system design, and note these insights for future projects.

For instance, avoid scenarios like this: rewriting all of your algae-related code in the middle of Worlds because you didn’t future-proof your code. I won’t make that mistake again.

Adopting good programming practices is essential. If you’re unfamiliar with design patterns, the off-season is an ideal time to learn.

Reviewing old code can also be engaging. For a hands-on experience, I sometimes print out a specific subsystem or module and annotate it manually. It’s both informative and relaxing.

Find a coding style that promotes modularity and ease of teaching.

### Logging
Implement a logging system, such as Advantage Scope, on an older competition bot. This tool can be invaluable for future debugging and analysis.

### Simulation and Fun Features
Simulations are a valuable resource. I strongly advise spending time on simulation to fix issues early, before even receiving the robot.

If you’re unfamiliar with simulations, start by reviewing the documentation.

This leads to an important tip for improving your programming skills:
- **Read the documentation**

I can’t emphasize enough how often this has saved me time. Instead of struggling for hours with a perplexing issue, a quick reference to the Java API (which should be bookmarked) can provide immediate solutions.

### Prepare New Members
As with any group, turnover is common in high school robotics. Team members rotate quickly, so ensure your team is prepared to onboard newcomers immediately. Train new members thoroughly during the off-season to equip them with the knowledge and confidence to handle any role. Don’t leave your team without someone who can step into any role effectively.

--- 

Let me know if you'd like any further adjustments!

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: Typically, investing time into vision and logging is a good idea. Reprogramming robots, whether this year’s or last year’s, is something worthwhile. Make sure it’s a swerve bot—it’s a good idea to create one because it allows you to build a swerve base easily. Take some time to explore code related to wrists, arms, elevators, different sensors, or to enhance your automation expertise. Another great project could be working with LEDs; they look impressive, provide wiring practice for your team, and are a fun side project.

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked: "Yep. The original version was released in April 2022… it works in simulation, so it just needs someone with an actual robot to test it in real life. I assume the lack of user interest is why it’s been ignored for three years, so I wouldn’t expect anyone to use it even if we do merge it."

Reflect on their methods and consider adopting what works best for you. Additionally, examining others’ styling or coding standards may offer useful practices to incorporate.

posts.name: Samjackjoetedpaulbill
posts.cooked:
Here’s the cleaned-up version of your text, maintaining its original meaning while improving readability and grammar:

---

Don’t just use LEDs for a cool factor; during gameplay, they should be visible to the driver as much as possible and provide feedback about the robot's status and tasks. This includes notifications like game piece acquired, April tag acquired, auto align complete, or if the game piece is stuck. Such information is valuable for reducing cycle times and quickly identifying issues to adjust the game plan accordingly—like checking if the intake is toast or jammed (e.g., detecting voltage spikes on intake motors), whether we can pivot to the other game piece, if we must play D because we only have a drivetrain now, or if the vision system is malfunctioning and the driver needs to switch to manual mode, etc.

---

This version preserves all key points from the original text while enhancing clarity and grammar.

posts.name: Josh
posts.cooked: That too, it’s definitely more of a good thing to get it under your belt and be ready to use it in future years. Personally, we added LEDs to last year’s robot to get a grasp on things and it looks awesome too.

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: As far as “things to build to be able to help lead the team”, I’d try some of the following: Get competent in simulations + Mechanism2D models so you and your team can program without hardware. Simulate and implement a robot of different design and slightly greater complexity than one your team built last season. Implement your existing robot in different ways such as full state machine command oriented partial state machines or just a full re-do if your current code is a disaster. Identify and resolve problems you had last season auto state handling path-planning vision feed-forwards whatever. Or resolve them in different manners than the one you ended up with. That one really cool thing you saw some other team do? Simulate and implement that. Repeat. Or in other words find where your limits currently are and push. Don’t worry about doing things perfectly just pick a thing work at it until you’re satisfied with the result then go do another thing. The goal here is to just diversify your experience but without getting too far away from the problems you’re likely to face next year given the constraints and capabilities of your program. This will help you understand where folks might be struggling when they need help and steer them towards solutions that might be better. Once you have folks up and running then is the time to have folks really dig into crunchier topics and “level up” your program with new technical expertise. For a leadership role practice I’d also suggest finding some local workshop or educational event and help out. When I’ve seen when students step into a leadership one of the tricky points is often figuring out how to answer questions and identify where folks struggle. Those beginner “learn to X” workshops are a great way to see folks struggle on “trivial” things and give you a number of opportunities to figure out how to identify what their issue is and get them moving past it without doing it for them. Plus this is a lot of fun and you’ll meet some great people doing it.
